title: AC Milan — from Champions League winners twice in five years and best team in Europe to Serie A also-rans in decade
text:
EFL Mil-lion miles away AC Milan — from Champions League winners twice in five years and best team in Europe to Serie A also-rans in decade 
Under Carlo Ancelotti, Rossoneri, reached latter stages of continent's premier competition annually: what has happened? By ANDREW RICHARDSON Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments RAFA BENITEZ angrily pointed to his watch as the referee blew his whistle two minutes into the three minutes of stoppage time allotted. 
But it was just a desperate attempt. Getty Images 24 AC Milan confirm status as Europe’s top dogs with 2007 Champions League win 
Liverpool had been comprehensively outplayed in Athens in 2007 — despite the seemingly close 2-1 scoreline — as a Filippo Inzaghi brace for AC Milan made it two Champions League victories in five years. 
Keep up to date with ALL the AC Milan news, gossip and transfers on our club page 
From 2003 to 2007, they had been kings of Europe twice and, in between, Carlo Ancelotti ’s men had reached the quarter-finals, final and semi-finals to establish themselves as the undoubted best team around. 
However, a decade on, the Rossoneri are a shadow of their former selves. 
We take a look back at how the seven-time European champions are now a team who treated winning this season’s Italian Super Cup — the equivalent of England’s Community Shield — a major success. 
Ancelotti was appointed Milan manager on November 6, 2001 — after four managers in nine months. Getty Images AC Milan reached three finals, a semi and quarter-final in amazing five years Getty Images AC Milan fans celebrate being crowned Serie A champions for 17th time in 2004 Getty Images 24 Carlo Ancelotti is hoisted into the air after winning Serie A with Milan in 2004 
It was somewhat of a gamble, as he was sacked just a year earlier by Juventus following two trophyless seasons. 
But the decision revolutionised the club, and he would win eight major trophies in eight seasons at the club. 
One of Ancelotti’s best traits has always been to get the best out his players — and this was never more evident that at Milan. AC Milan: 2007 Champions League final line-up 
GK: Dida 24 Kaka and Massimo Oddo celebrate Champions League success in Athens in 2007 
Paolo Maldini was 33 when he arrived, Alessandro Costacurta, 35, while Inzaghi was 28 and he signed Clarence Seedorf at the age of 26 a year on. 
The quartet were still with the team when they beat Liverpool in Athens on May 23, 2007. 
Aside from Kaka , who was 25 at the time, every other starting player was 28 or above — with only three under the age of 30. 
Of course, sooner or later, these men would have to retire. 
But, the issue of replacing them should have been a gradual process initiated before they departed. Getty Images Carlo Ancelotti waves to AC Milan fans after 2007 Champions League triumph Related Articles Don't blow chances Italian model on 'million men' referendum sex tour reveals she will perform sex acts on ENTIRE Napoli team if they win Champions League Preview What Champions League games are on this week? PSG vs Barca, Bayern vs Arsenal and Real Madrid vs Napoli FOOTBALL ON TV What football is on TV today? Our guide to this week's live matches War favours Gunners Arsenal given boost with Bayern's German and foreign stars at war a week before crunch clash SECRET WEAPON Arsene Wenger surprises Arsenal fans by naming Yaya Sanogo in Champions League squad Getty Images 24 Clarence Seedorf was at heart of midfield which won two Champions League titles 
Milan were already showing signs of decline by 2009, with the quality to replace the ageing players unavailable. 
A last-16 elimination from the Champions League in 2007-08 was coupled with a fifth-place finish and qualification for the Uefa Cup — where they were knocked out by Werder Bremen in the round of 32. 
Costacurta, who had been with the club since 1986, retired immediately after the 2007 Champions League final. AP:Associated Press Filippo Inzaghi scored twice as AC Milan beat Liverpool to win 2007 Champs Lge Epa 24 Filippo Inzaghi shows his joy at Champions League-winning double in 2007 
Ancelotti stepped down in the summer of 2009 to take over as boss of Chelsea having led the club back into Europe’s elite competition — at the same as legendary Maldini called time on his incredible 24-year-long career. 
Meanhwhile, Kaka, who was tipped to eventually have his name alongside the club’s greats and had won the Ballon d’Or in 2007, joined Real Madrid in a stunning summer of upheaval. 
Former midfielder, Leonardo, was named in the hotseat for his first-ever managerial role, and Massimo Ambrosini, at the age of 32, was named club captain. Action Images Alessandro Nesta was still at top of his game at age of 31 with Milan in 2007 PA:Press Association 24 Andrea Pirlo celebrates second Champions League triumph in five years 
Ronaldinho had arrived in 2008 as the board looked to breathe new life into the club, but he, too, was far from the player he had once been. 
Milan finished third — 12 points behind rivals, Inter, who would win the Treble — and were battered 4-0 by Manchester United in the Champions League. 
Leonardo stepped down and was replaced by Max Allegri, who brought in Zlatan Ibrahimovic on loan and looked to be building another strong team. Reuters 24 Andrea Pirlo was allowed to join Juventus on a free and in 2011 actually improved 
Robinho, Alexandre Pato alongside the Swede — with Antonio Cassano in reserve — were billed as a new superstar strike force. 
They won the 2010-11 title, and the club saw this as the opportunity to began the overhaul process. 
Milan decided, inexplicably, not to renew Andrea Pirlo ’s contract, and the midfielder joined Juventus — and won Serie A Player of the Year three seasons in a row. 
A year on, the Bianconeri won the Scudetto and Milan finished second. Aflo Images An AC Milan starting line-up 2013, bereft of stars, shows the impact of decline Reuters Alexandre Pato, Robinho and Thiago Silva celebrate final title success in 2011 
In the summer of 2012 a staggering overhaul took place. 
Ibrahimovic and star defender, Thiago Silva, joined ambitious Paris Saint-Germain , while Alessandro Nesta, Inzaghi, Gennari Gattuso and Seedorf were all released. 
Along with veterans, Gianluca Zambrotta and Mark van Bommel , who had arrived more recently. 
While Pato and Cassano also left, as Milan conceded defeat in their bid to build the super strike force. 
Did the club think their 2003-07 team would last forever? Getty Images ‘Superstar strike-force’ of Alexandre Pato and Zlatan Ibrahimovic wholly failed Getty Images Mario Balotelli was signed from Manchester City in 2013, but made little impact Getty Images 24 Veteran Mark van Bommel was allowed to leave along with many others in 2012 
No plans were put in place to replace them and the club moved to overhaul this incredible team in such a short space of time. 
Former Portsmouth star, Kevin Prince-Boateng, Mario Balotelli and Stephan El-Shaaraway now made up the front three. 
While Christian Abbiati, who had been at the club as a No.2 since 1998 was suddenly deemed good enough to start. AC Milan line-up vs Bologna: Feb 8, 2017
